sentences.sentence: We had no sooner run to look, than the ship struck upon sand.
The sea broke over the ship in such a manner that we expected to die at once.
It is not easy for anyone who has not been in a similar situation, to describe how men feel in such circumstances( 情形 ): we knew nothing of where we were, or upon what land it was we were driven.
As the force of the wind was still great, we could not hope to have the ship hold many minutes without breaking into pieces.
We had a boat on board, but getting it into the sea was a doubtful thing.
The captain of our ship grabbed hold of( 抓住 ) the boat, and with the help of the rest of the men threw it over the ship’s side.
All getting all into it, we let go, and gave ourselves up to( 屈服于… ) the wild sea.
And now our situation was very bad indeed, for we all saw plainly that the sea went so high that the boat could not survive, and that we would be drowned( 淹死 ).
An enormous( 巨大的 ) wave came rolling toward us, and we all expected that this was the end.
It took us with such a force, that it turned the boat over at once.
Separating us from the boat as well as from one another, the wave swallowed us up in a moment.
Nothing can describe the confusion( 不知所措 ) I felt when I sank into the water.
Though I swam very well, I could not save myself from the waves long enough to breathe.
I held my breath( 屏住呼吸 ), and swam forward with all my strength.
I was ready to burst( 快要憋不住… ) from holding my breath, when I found my head and hands shoot out above the surface of the water.
Though it only lasted for two seconds, it gave me breath and new courage.
I was covered again with water for a good while, and the sea hurried me along as before.
This time it threw me against a rock, with such force that it left me senseless.
I recovered a little before the return of the waves, and decided to hold on to the rock till the wave passed, and then ride the next wave towards the shore.
At last I got to the land, where I climbed up the rocks along the shore and sat down upon the grass, free from danger, and quite out of the reach of the water.
I was now on land and safe, and began to look up and thank God that my life was saved.
However, I soon came to realize that all my comrades were drowned( 淹死 ), for I never saw them again, or any sign of them.
I began to look round me, to see what kind of place I was in, and what was to be done next.

I was wet, had no clothes, nor anything to eat or drink, and no weapons( 武器 ) to hunt and kill any creature for food. In a word, I had nothing except a small knife, a tobacco pipe, and a little tobacco in a box.
First, I looked around for a while, and found a small stream of fresh water nearby, from which I drank.
Then, since night was coming, I began to worry what would happen to me if there were any wild animals nearby, because hunting animals always feed( 进食 ) during the night.
The only solution I could think of at that time was to climb up into a thick bushy tree, where I decided to sit all night.
I put a little tobacco into my mouth to prevent hunger, and cut a short stick to defend myself.
I fell fast asleep( 入睡 ), and slept as comfortably as I could, given( 考虑到 ) the situation.
When I awoke it was the middle of the day.
The weather had cleared, and the storm had passed, so that the sea did not rise and swell( 涨潮 ) as before.
But what surprised me most was that the ship had moved during the night, and was driven within about a mile from the shore where I was.
I wished myself on board, that, at least, I might save some necessary things for my use.
A little after noon I found the sea very calm, and the water level so much lower that I could come within a quarter of a mile of the ship.
And here I found a fresh renewing( 更新 ) of my despair( 绝望 ), for I saw that if we had kept on board, we would have all got safe on shore.
This forced tears to my eyes again, but as there was little relief in that, I decided to get to the ship.
By the help of a rope hanging down, I got up into the front of the ship. You may be sure my first work was to search and to see what was ruined, and what was still usable.
First, I found that all the ship’s food was dry and untouched by the water, and being very hungry, I went to the bread-room and filled my pockets with biscuits.
Now what I wanted most was a boat, to take the many things that I was going to need.
On the ship were several large pieces of wood, and a spare mast( 桅杆 ).
I threw as much wood into the sea as I could find, tying it all together with a rope, to make a raft( 木筏 ).
I next thought about what to load it with.
I got three large wooden storage boxes, and lowered them down upon my raft( 木筏 ).
The first of these I filled with food: bread, rice, three Dutch( 荷兰的 ) cheeses, and five pieces of dried goat meat.
I also found European corn, which we had brought for some birds which we brought to sea with us, but the birds were killed.
There had been some rice and wheat, but to my great disappointment, I found afterwards( 之后 ) that the rats had eaten it all.
As for wine, I found several cases of bottles belonging to( 属于 ) our ship, in all about five or six gallons( 加仑 ).
I searched for( 搜寻 ) clothes, of which I found enough, but took no more than I wanted for present use.
Next, I looked for tools to work with on shore, and after much searching I found the carpenter( 木匠 )’s tool box, which was a very useful prize to me.
My next need was for some weapons( 武器 ). There were two very good bird guns in the ship, and two pistols( 手枪 ).
I knew there were three barrels( 桶 ) of gunpowder( 火药 ) in the ship, and with much searching I found two of them.
Those two I got to my raft( 木筏 ), with the weapons( 武器 ).
And now I thought my boat was pretty well stocked( 囤货的 ), and so I set out into the sea.
My raft( 木筏 ) went very well. I hoped to find a river, which I might follow to land with my supplies.
I found a little stream, so I guided my raft( 木筏 ) as well as I could, to keep in the middle of the stream.
Finally I saw a small bay on the right shore of the stream, to which, with great difficulty, I guided my raft( 木筏 ).
I pushed my raft( 木筏 ) up on a flat piece of ground, and there fastened it.
My next work was to view the country, and seek a proper place for shelter( 住所 ), where I could keep my supplies to save them from whatever might happen.
Whether I was on a continent or on an island I didn’t know yet, nor whether there were others living here.
There was a hill, not more than a mile from me, which seemed taller than the other hills.
I took one of the bird guns, and one of the pistols( 手枪 ). Thus armed, I traveled up to the top of that hill.
When I reached the peak( 山峰 ), I saw that I was on an island, surrounded( 包围 ) in every direction by the sea.
I found also that the island was empty of people, nor did I see any animals.
Yet I saw many birds, and as I was coming back, I shot a large bird, which I saw sitting upon a tree.
I believe it was the first gun that had been fired there since the creation of the world.
I had no sooner fired, than from all parts of the wood, a great number of birds flew up.
As for the creature I killed, I took it to be a kind of hawk( 鹰 ), but its meat was not fit for eating.
Happy with this discovery, I came back to my raft( 木筏 ), and went to work to bring my supplies on shore.
As well as I could, I surrounded( 将...包围 ) myself with the boxes and boards that I had brought on shore, and made a kind of shelter( 住所 ) for that night.
I now began to hope that I might still get a great many useful things out of the ship.
I particularly wanted some of the ropes and sails, and I decided to make another voyage to the ship.
I got on board the ship as before, and prepared a second raft( 木筏 ), and so brought away several things very useful to me.
First, in the carpenter( 木匠 )’s stores, I found two or three bags full of nails, a dozen axes( 斧头 ), and most usefully a thing called a grindstone( 磨石 ).
All these I took, together with two barrels( 枪管 ) of bullets( 子弹 ) and seven guns.
Besides these things, I took all the men’s clothes that I could find, as well as a hammock( 吊床 ) and some bedding( 寝具 ).
With this I loaded my second raft( 木筏 ), and brought them all safe on shore, to my very great comfort.
Having got my second load on shore, I went to work to make a little tent with the sail and some poles( 杆 ).
Into this tent I brought everything that I knew would spoil( 损坏 ) either with rain or sun.
When I had done this, I blocked up the door of the tent with some boards.
Spreading some of the bedding( 寝具 ) upon the ground, and laying two pistols( 手枪 ) just at my head, and my gun just by me, I went to bed for the first time. I slept very quietly all night.
I believe I now had the biggest store of supplies that ever was made for one man.
But I was not satisfied still, for while the ship sat close to shore, I thought I ought to get everything out of it that I could.
So every day, at low water, I went on board and brought away something or other.

question.cn: 当他们看到沙滩的时候，他们知道自己到哪儿了吗？
question.en: Did they know where they could land when they saw the sand?

analysis: 文中说：“We knew nothing of where we were, or upon what land it was we were driven. ”所以选B。

question.cn: 在岛上的第一天夜里，Robinson吃什么充饥？
question.en: On the first night on the Island, what did Robinson eat to prevent hunger?

analysis: 文中说：“I put a little tobacco into my mouth to prevent hunger...”所以选C。

question.cn: Robinson用什么把他在船上找到的东西运上岸？
question.en: What did Robinson use to carry the things he found on the ship to the shore?

analysis: 文中说：“Now what I wanted most was a boat, to take the many things that I was going to need.”但是他没有找到小船，所以，“I threw as much wood into the sea as I could find, tying it all together with a rope, to make a raft.”所以选B。

question.en: Where did Robinson land his raft ?

analysis: 文中说：“Finally I saw a small bay on the right shore of the stream, to which, with great difficulty, I guided my raft. I pushed my raft up on a flat piece of ground, and there fastened it.”所以选A。

question.cn: 岛上除了Robinson还有别的人吗？
question.en: Were there any human beings on the island except Robinson?

analysis: 文中说：“I found also that the island was empty of people, nor did I see any animals. ”所以选B。
